author: wired blogs
text: date: fri, 22 oct 1999 13:49:14 -0700 from: eric johnson (johnsone@corp.home.net)to: newsfeedback@wired.comsubject: right of privacy?i was reading the article about echelon ("monitor this, echelon," 22.oct.99). you quoted this person as saying "...i took an oath to defend the constitution," he said. "i still honor that oath."the us constitution guarantees the right of privacy, and that should extend to fax, email, and telephone communications, slaughter said. "i think we need to honor those things." if memory serves me correctly "privacy" is not one of the rights given to americans by the constitution. where it may be nice to have and we like to dupe ourselves into believing that our government guarantees us privacy, you, in the interest of good news reporting are obliged to clarify fact from fiction. bottom line: i disagree with the comment that we are guaranteed a right of privacy by the constitution. either i or macki are mistaken.
